title: Bank of England probes insurers’ cyber defences
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Wed, Aug 19, 2015, 14:12 BST - UK Markets close in 2 hrs 18 mins Bank of England probes insurers’ cyber defences By Tim Wallace | Telegraph – 14 minutes ago 0.0001 
Officials want to see if finance firms have improved their resilience to hackers and other online attackers 
Britain’s insurance firms are under pressure to improve their defences against cyber attacks, as the Bank of England conducts a survey to check up on progress in the sector. 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) comes after Bank governor Mark Carney highlighted cyber attacks as a key risk to the financial sector, calling for the resilience of firms to be “regularly assessed” to cope with the “adaptive nature of the threat”. 
And last month defence chiefs from both sides of the Atlantic warned the City of London that attacks from aggressive nations like Russia were an increasing threat. 
When the finance sector was surveyed in 2012, the Bank of England found that although firms were starting to take cyber security seriously, bosses across the financial sector were still paying too little attention to the risk posed by hackers. 
“In total, 97pc of all participants reported [in 2012] that they discuss technology and cyber resilience during top management meetings. However, only around half of participants reported that they discuss these issues monthly or quarterly,” the Bank of England said on Wednesday. 
“Given the significant increase in cyber-attacks on financial firms since this survey was completed, we would expect that proportion to have increased in the ensuing period.” 
This latest study will seek to find out if insurers have made more progress since then. 
The Bank of England will ask 28 multiple choice questions , with some additional space for extra information. They range from the basics, such as asking insurers if their senior managers understand their roles and responsibilities, through to the more complex, such as questions on the type of incidents the firm would investigate. 
At the bottom of the survey, it leaves space for the Prudential Regulation Authority to add up the answers, counting the number of times the firm gave the response A, B or C. 
Insurers are also asked if they offer cyber insurance products to other companies. 
The Financial Conduct Authority joins the PRA in asking about this part of the business, to find out what data insurers hold on their customers with regard to cyber security. 
They have 10 weeks to send the forms back to Threadneedle Street.
